_comment: Created by JMorris on 09/05/2018 14:43:17 using v2.7
title: How does the UK's infant mortality rate compare internationally?
analysis_commentary:
The infant mortality rate has been decreasing in all OECD countries since 2000. The UK has a relatively high rate of infant mortality compared to other countries with 3.9 deaths per 1,000 live births in 2015. The country with the highest rate each year is the United States while Japan, Finland and Sweden have the lowest rates.

One of the United Nations Millennium Development Goals was to reduce child mortality by two-thirds between 1990 and 2015. According to this, the UK should have reduced the 1990 infant mortality rate of 7.9 deaths per 1,000 live births to 2.6 by 2015. The UK only managed to reduce its infant mortality rate by one half, so did not meet this target. In 2015, the MDGs were replaced by the Sustainable Development Goals where maternal and child health remains key to Goal 3, "ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages".

Updated April 2018.
data_source: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, Health Statistics 2017
